[[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency Law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] |date=January 2011}}, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref>, and continuously in effect since [[Anwar El Sadat]]'s 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalised,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/ |title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States |date=26 March 2004 |accessdate=30 January 2011 |last=Shehata |first=Samer |work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organisations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw"/>
The Mubarak government has used the reason of [[terrorism]] to continue extending emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> and has claimed that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections, confiscate the group's main financiers' possessions, and detain group figureheads—actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{cite book |last= Caraley |first= Demetrios |title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy |publisher= [[Academy of Political Science]] |year= 2004 |month= April |isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> Pro-democracy advocates in Egypt argue that this goes against the principles of [[democracy]], which include a citizen's [[right to a fair trial]] and their [[Suffrage|right to vote]] for whichever candidate or party they choose. Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> and that in the 1990s the number of detainees was over 20,000.<ref name="eohr2008"/><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=R.
